Article.Abstract: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is thought to involve CD4 T cell recognition of self myelin, many studies focusing on a pathogenic role for anti-myelin, HLA-DR15-restricted T cells. In experimental allergic encephalomyelitis, it is known which epitopes trigger disease and that disease is associated with determinant spread of T cell reactivity. Characterization of these events in human MS is critical for the development of peptide immunotherapies, but it has been difficult to define the role of determinant spread or define which epitopes might be involved. In this study, we report humanized transgenic mice, strongly expressing HLA-DR15 with an MS-derived TCR; even on a RAG-2 wild-type background, mice spontaneously develop paralysis. Disease, involving demyelination and axonal degeneration, correlates with inter- and intramolecular spread of the T cell response to HLA-DR15-restricted epitopes of myelin basic protein, myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein, and alphaB-crystallin. Spread is reproducible and progressive, with two of the epitopes commonly described in responses of HLA-DR15 patients. The fact that this pattern is reiterated as a consequence of CNS tissue damage in mice demonstrates the value of the transgenic model in supplying an in vivo disease context for the human responses. This model, encompassing pathologically relevant, spontaneous disease with the presentation of myelin epitopes in the context of HLA-DR15, should offer new insights and predictions about T cell responses during MS as well as a more stringent test bed for immunotherapies.
Article.ArticleTitle: High incidence of spontaneous disease in an HLA-DR15 and TCR transgenic multiple sclerosis model.
Article.Affiliations: Human Disease Immunogenetics Group, Department of Infectious Diseases and Transplantation Biology Group, Medical Research Council Clinical Sciences Centre, Imperial College, Hammersmith Hospital, London, United Kingdom.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CD4+ and CD8+ purified cells populations both gave similar positive proliferative responses in response to the epitope.

Both CD4+ splenocytes and PGF DR15+ B-cells were pulsed with MBP 85-89 peptide prior to their addition together for this assay. Though the TCR was of human origin, the cells bearing them were of transgenic mouse origin. CD8+ cells were also used and both were found to have the capacity to lyse peptide-pulsed targets.

IFN-Î³ release in response to epitope from determinant spreading were compared between spleen cells and infiltrating T-cells from CNS. This epitope only produced a significant proliferative responses in T-cells from CNS.

IL-4 secretion responses to epitope from determinant spreading were compared between spleen cells and infiltrating T-cells from CNS. This epitope produced a small but comparable response to both sources of T-cells.
Determinant spreading analysis was performed in mice with EAE. This is the only other Myelin Basic Protein determinant that appeared within the MBP protein sequence.

Proliferative responses to epitope from determinant spreading were compared between spleen cells and infiltrating T-cells from CNS. This epitope produced significant proliferative responses in both groups of cells.

Il-2 release in response to the epitope from determinant spreading were compared between spleen cells and infiltrating T-cells from CNS. This epitope produced a small but significant response in both groups of cells.

Proliferative responses to epitope from determinant spreading were compared between spleen cells and infiltrating T-cells from CNS. This epitope produced significant proliferative responses in both groups of cells.

IFN-Î³ release in response to epitope from determinant spreading were compared between spleen cells and infiltrating T-cells from CNS. This epitope produced a robust response in CNS cells and small response in splenocytes.

IL-4 release response to epitope from determinant spreading compared between spleen cells and infiltrating T-cells from CNS. This epitope produced a small but significant response in both groups of cells.

IFN-Î³ release in response toepitope from determinant spreading was compared between spleen cells and infiltrating T-cells from CNS. This epitope only produced a small but detectable response from CNS infiltrating cells.
